Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with diabetes and cirrhosis who presented to the emergency department in septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis. He has developed multi-organ system failure, including encephalopathy, seizures, hypotension, and acute oliguric renal failure. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has a central venous catheter, arterial line, and dialysis catheter in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Increased risk of sepsis-related mortality due to multi-organ system failure and listeriosis.
2. Development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and potential DIC.
4. Development of acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to continued oliguria and potential nephrotoxicity of antibiotics.
5. Development of liver failure or worsening of cirrhosis due to ongoing sepsis and potential liver toxicity of antibiotics.
6. Development of cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure due to ongoing sepsis and potential cardiotoxicity of antibiotics.
7. Development of respiratory failure due to continued mechanical ventilation and potential respiratory muscle weakness.
8. Development of nosocomial infections, such as catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI) or surgical site infections (SSIs).
9. Development of electrolyte imbalances or acid-base disturbances due to ongoing sepsis and potential electrolyte wasting.
10. Development of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to ongoing sepsis and potential gastrointestinal toxicity of antibiotics.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy as prescribed, and monitor for signs of sepsis and multi-organ system failure.
2. Monitor for signs of VAP, and consider empiric antibiotics if suspected.
3. Monitor for signs of bleeding or DIC, and consider transfusions if necessary.
4. Monitor renal function and consider dialysis if oliguria persists.
5. Monitor liver function and consider liver transplantation if liver failure occurs.
6. Monitor cardiac function and consider cardiology consultation if cardiac arrhythmias or failure occur.
7. Monitor respiratory function and consider weaning from mechanical ventilation if possible.
8. Monitor for signs of nosocomial infections, and consider empiric antibiotics if suspected.
9. Monitor electrolyte levels and acid-base status, and consider correction if necessary.
10. Monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation, and consider endoscopy or surgery if necessary.

   Assessment and Plan: 76M with DM and cirrhosis presented to an OSH in
   septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis now w/ multiorgansystem
   failure and seizures.
   * Altered mental status:
   Persists w/o signs of improvement, probably multifactorial with CNS
   listerial infection, seizures, hepatic encephalopathy.  Not interactive
   off of sedatives.
   - Neurology input appreciated.
   - treat seizures as below
   - attempt to wean propofol
   .
   *. Seizures.  Pt has had multiple seizures may be due to CNS listeria
   infection. CT head noncontrast without mass or abscess.
   EEG showed persistent seizure activity.
   - Ativan prn
   - Neuro recs appreciated
   - Now on dilantin, checking regular and free dilantin levels and will
   f/u w/ neurology re dosing given artificially elevated albumin
   - started phenobarbital
   - discuss with neuro re: utility of repeat imaging vs. LP
   *. Listeriosis with bacteremia and septic shock.  Likely c/b meningitis
   as presented w/ HA and lethargy.
   - Blood cx here pending w/ NGTD
   - Reculture if febrile, follow up pending micro at OSH re sensitivities
   - Continue ampicilin dose for CVVH. Added TMP-SMX for synergy.
   Anticipate 6 week course of amp, probably 3 week course of TMP-SMX
   - ID recommending LP - but very likely had meningitis would favor just
   treating him with 6wk CNS course. Will discuss with neuro re: ultility
   of LP
   - ID recs appreciated
   .
   * Hypotension
   Unclear etiology although clinically seems most consistent w/ sepsis
   (now w/ low-grade fevers on CVVH).  Mvo2 more consistent with
   cardiogenic than septic etiology (although unclear if CVVH could affect
   this).
   Multiple possible contributors including meds (eg ativan, dilantin),
   sepsis, volume removal with CVVH, poor pump function. Adrenal
   insufficiency also a possibility. On levophed currently
   - Cortisol level not drastically low
   - Follow up cultures, CIS, infection tx as above
   - Continue levophed target MAP>60 -> attempt to wean
   - Follow lactate daily, recently stable
   - Will change CVVH to run even to see if this improves hypotension
   .
   * r/o Ventilator acquired pneumonia
   Sputum without pathogen identified yet. Temp curve improving on
   antibiotics
   - Continue zosyn x8d course (d1 = [**5-10**])
   - Will D/C vanco
   - Follow up pending cultures and CIS
   .
   *. Acute oliguric renal failure: Most likely from ATN in the setting of
   hypotension.  Not fluid responsive.
   DDx includes ATN in setting of sepsis and recent vol depletion from
   diarrhea. Also consider HRS given cirrhosis. Abdominal compartment
   syndrome seems un likely. No IV contrast, from what I can tell from
   records. Could have AIN in the setting of abx but I think less likely.
   Renal U/S w/o hydro.
   - CVVH for now, but will run even now to see if this improves
   hypotensiion
   - Appreciate continued renal input
   *. Transaminitis with history of cirrhosis.
   LFTS have been trending down
   In setting of sepsis likely from shock liver. DDx includes med
   toxicity, hepatic congestion in setting of low EF. Acute infectious
   hepatitis less likely.
   - Continue albumin 50mg [**Hospital1 **] per hepatology recommendations
   - Continue to trends LFTs daily
   - Holding spironolactone
   - Liver following
   - elevated bilis may reflect lag in liver recovery. Also consider
   contrib from hemolysis (DIC). Check D bili today.
   *. Systolic heart failure w/ EF 15% from either recent or remote MI.
   - Continue ASA, BB
   - Monitor on telemetry given NSVT
   * DIC
   Fibrinogen continues to be low but will not give cryo given that he
   does not have any active bleeding
   - monitor fibrinogen.
   *. Tachyarrhythmia.  Pt had runsNSVT, maintained BP at the time. Likely
   predisposed with low EF, systemic infection, acid base disturbance in
   setting of renal failure
   - Continue monitoring on telemetry and continue metoprolol
   - Will keep pads on for now
   * Anemia:  Microcytic.  Drop from admission in setting of IVF. Stable
   on serial checks since yesterday. Pt did have borderline fibrinogen
   concerning for DIC
   - DIC labs daily
   - daily hct, transfuse hb>7, T+S
   * Thrombocytopenia: Likely from cirrhosis.  ? from DIC.
   - DIC labs daily
   *. DM
   - Hold home metformin
   - Insulin sliding scale, goal glucose <150
   ICU Care

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of diabetes and cirrhosis who presented to the emergency department in septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis. The patient has developed multi-organ system failure, including encephalopathy, seizures, renal failure, and hypotension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 360. The patient has minimal bibasilar atelectasis and a small right basal effusion on chest X-ray.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, likely due to CNS listerial infection, seizures, and hepatic encephalopathy. The patient has had multiple seizures and is currently on dilantin and phenobarbital.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hypotension, likely due to sepsis, and is receiving norepinephrine infusion. The patient has a low ejection fraction (EF) of 15%, and is at risk for cardiogenic shock.
* Renal: The patient has acute oliguric renal failure, likely due to ATN in the setting of hypotension. The patient is receiving CVVH and will continue to run even to see if this improves hypotension.
* Hepatic: The patient has transaminitis, likely due to sepsis and shock liver. The patient is receiving albumin and will continue to trend LFTs daily.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia, likely due to IVF and borderline fibrinogen, which is concerning for DIC. The patient is also thrombocytopenic, likely due to cirrhosis and possible DIC.
* Endocrine: The patient has diabetes, and is receiving insulin sliding scale and metformin is being held.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Ventilator-acquired pneumonia (VAP)
* Central nervous system (CNS) complications, such as meningitis or abscess
* Cardiogenic shock
* Renal failure progression
* Hepatic failure
* Hemorrhagic complications due to DIC
* Sepsis-related mortality

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for listeriosis and sepsis
* CVVH for renal failure
* Albumin for transaminitis
* Insulin sliding scale for diabetes
* Corticosteroids for adrenal insufficiency
* Vasopressors for hypotension
* Monitoring for VAP and CNS complications
* Close monitoring of renal and hepatic function

The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities. The patient is experiencing:

1. Encephalopathy, likely related to sepsis and potential meningitis.
2. Renal failure, acute, with a creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL.
3. Seizures, which are being managed with anticonvulsant medications.
4. Hypotension, which is being treated with norepinephrine infusion.
5. Respiratory failure, acute, requiring mechanical ventilation.
6. Myocardial infarction, acute, with elevated troponin levels.
7. Sepsis, severe, with organ dysfunction.
8. Hepatic encephalopathy, likely related to liver dysfunction.
9. Hyperkalemia, with a potassium level of 5.4 mmol/L.
10. Ineffective coping, likely related to the patient's critical illness.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Further deterioration of renal function, leading to acute kidney injury or end-stage renal disease.
2. Increased risk of bleeding due to anticoagulant therapy and platelet dysfunction.
3. Development of secondary infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI).
4. Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to myocardial infarction and electrolyte imbalances.
5. Neurological complications, such as stroke or cerebral edema, due to sepsis and encephalopathy.
6. Hepatic failure, leading to coagulopathy and increased risk of bleeding.
7. Respiratory failure, requiring escalation of ventilator support or consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
8. Sepsis-induced multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), leading to further deterioration of multiple organ systems.

Given the patient's critical condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of their vital signs, laboratory results, and medication regimen. Regular reassessment and adjustments to their care plan are necessary to prevent and manage potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan: 76M with DM and cirrhosis presented to an OSH in

   failure and seizures.
   * Altered mental status:
   Persists w/o signs of improvement, probably multifactorial with CNS
   listerial infection, seizures, hepatic encephalopathy.  Not interactive
   off of sedatives.
   - Neurology input appreciated.
   - treat seizures as below
   .
   *. Seizures.  Pt has had multiple seizures may be due to CNS listeria
   infection. CT head noncontrast without mass or abscess.
   EEG showed persistent seizure activity.
   - Ativan prn
   - Neuro recs appreciated
   - Now on dilantin, checking regular and free dilantin levels and will
   f/u w/ neurology re dosing given artificially elevated albumin
   *. Listeriosis with bacteremia and septic shock.  Likely c/b meningitis
   as presented w/ HA and lethargy.
   - Blood cx here pending w/ NGTD
   - Reculture if febrile, follow up pending micro at OSH re sensitivities
   - Continue ampicilin dose for CVVH. Added TMP-SMX for synergy.
   Anticipate 6 week course of amp, probably 3 week course of TMP-SMX
   - ID recommending LP - but very likely had meningitis would favor just
   treating him with 6wk CNS course. Hold on LP for now given hemodynamic
   instability
   - ID recs appreciated
   .
   * Hypotension
   Unclear etiology although clinically seems most consistent w/ sepsis
   (now w/ low-grade fevers on CVVH).  Mvo2 more consistent with
   cardiogenic than septic etiology (although unclear if CVVH could affect
   this).
   Multiple possible contributors including meds (eg ativan, dilantin),
   sepsis, volume removal with CVVH, poor pump function. Adrenal
   insufficiency also a possibility. On levophed currently
   - Consider checking cortisol level in am if still on pressors
   - Follow up cultures, CIS, infection tx as above
   - Continue levophed target MAP>60
   - Follow lactate daily, recently stable
   .
   * r/o Ventilator acquired pneumonia
   Sputum without pathogen identified yet. Temp curve improving on
   antibiotics
   - Continue vancomycin and zosyn x8d course (d1 = [**5-10**])
   - Follow up pending cultures and CIS
   .
   *. Acute oliguric renal failure: Most likely from ATN in the setting of
   hypotension.  Not fluid responsive.
   DDx includes ATN in setting of sepsis and recent vol depletion from
   diarrhea. Also consider HRS given cirrhosis. Abdominal compartment
   syndrome seems un likely. No IV contrast, from what I can tell from
   records. Could have AIN in the setting of abx but I think less likely.
   Renal U/S w/o hydro.
   - CVVH for now, 50cc/hr off
   - Appreciate continued renal input
   *. Transaminitis with history of cirrhosis.
   LFTS have been trending down
   In setting of sepsis likely from shock liver. DDx includes med
   toxicity, hepatic congestion in setting of low EF. Acute infectious
   hepatitis less likely.
   - Continue albumin 50mg [**Hospital1 **] per hepatology recommendations
   - Continue to trends LFTs daily
   - Holding spironolactone
   - Liver following
   - elevated bilis may reflect lag in liver recovery. Also consider
   contrib from hemolysis (DIC). Check D bili today.
   *. Systolic heart failure w/ EF 15% from either recent or remote MI.
   - Continue ASA, BB
   - Monitor on telemetry given NSVT
   * DIC
   Fibrinogen continues to be low but will not give cryo given that he
   does not have any active bleeding.
   *. Tachyarrhythmia.  Pt had runsNSVT, maintained BP at the time. Likely
   predisposed with low EF, systemic infection, acid base disturbance in
   setting of renal failure
   - Continue monitoring on telemetry and continue metoprolol
   - Will keep pads on for now
   * Anemia:  Microcytic.  Drop from admission in setting of IVF. Stable
   on serial checks since yesterday. Pt did have borderline fibrinogen
   concerning for DIC
   - DIC labs daily
   - daily hct, transfuse hb>7, T+S
   * Thrombocytopenia: Likely from cirrhosis.  ? from DIC.
   - DIC labs daily

   - Hold home metformin

   - Appreciate continued renal input

   LFTS have been trending down
   In setting of sepsis likely from shock liver. DDx includes med
   toxicity, hepatic congestion in setting of low EF. Acute infectious
   hepatitis less likely.
   - Continue albumin 50mg [**Hospital1 **] per hepatology recommendations
   - Continue to trends LFTs daily
   - Holding spironolactone
   - Liver following
   - elevated bilis may reflect lag in liver recovery. Also consider
   contrib from hemolysis (DIC). Check D bili today.

   - Continue ASA, BB
   - Monitor on telemetry given NSVT
   * DIC
   Fibrinogen continues to be low but will not give cryo given that he
   does not have any active bleeding.
   *. Tachyarrhythmia.  Pt had runsNSVT, maintained BP at the time. Likely
   predisposed with low EF, systemic infection, acid base disturbance in
   setting of renal failure
   - Continue monitoring on telemetry and continue metoprolol

   * Anemia:  Microcytic.  Drop from admission in setting of IVF. Stable
   on serial checks since yesterday. Pt did have borderline fibrinogen
   concerning for DIC

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications have arisen:

1. **Seizures**: The patient has had multiple seizures, which may be due to CNS listeria infection. The patient is currently on dilantin and phenobarbital for burst suppression.
2. **Septic Shock**: The patient presented to the hospital in septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and the ID team is recommending a 6-week course of antibiotics.
3. **Multi-Organ System Failure**: The patient has developed multi-organ system failure, including renal failure, hepatic failure, and cardiac failure.
4. **Acute Oliguric Renal Failure**: The patient's renal failure is likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) in the setting of hypotension and sepsis.
5. **Transaminitis**: The patient has developed transaminitis, which is likely due to sepsis and shock liver.
6. **Systolic Heart Failure**: The patient has developed systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15%, which is likely due to recent or remote myocardial infarction.
7. **Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)**: The patient has developed DIC, which is likely due to sepsis and multi-organ system failure.
8. **Tachyarrhythmia**: The patient has developed NSVT, which is likely due to low ejection fraction, systemic infection, and acid-base disturbance in the setting of renal failure.
9. **Anemia**: The patient has developed anemia, which is likely due to microcytic anemia and blood loss.
10. **Thrombocytopenia**: The patient has developed thrombocytopenia, which is likely due to cirrhosis and possibly DIC.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated bilirubin levels
* Elevated lactate levels
* Low fibrinogen levels
* Low platelet count
* Elevated creatinine levels
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels
* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST, and Alk Phos)

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: minimal bibasilar atelectasis and a small right basal effusion
* CT head: non-contrast, no mass or abscess
* Renal U/S: no hydro

The patient's medical treatment includes:

* Antibiotics for sepsis and listeriosis
* CVVH for renal failure
* Albumin for liver failure
* ASA and BB for systolic heart failure
* Metoprolol for tachyarrhythmia
* Insulin sliding scale for diabetes
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis, acute myocardial infarction, sepsis, acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and hepatic encephalopathy. The patient is sedated and has a distended abdomen, likely due to ascites. The patient's condition is unstable, with ongoing seizures, hypotension, and respiratory failure. The patient requires ongoing treatment for possible infection, including antibiotics and anticonvulsants. The patient's cardiac status is also a concern, with ongoing treatment for myocardial infarction and possible cardiogenic shock.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis is severe, and the risk of organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and hepatic dysfunction, is high.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen, leading to ventilator-dependent respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's acute myocardial infarction may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's ongoing seizures may lead to further neurological damage, and the risk of brain death or permanent neurological damage is high.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's distended abdomen and possible ascites may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
6. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to end-stage renal disease or the need for dialysis.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
8. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's hepatic encephalopathy may worsen, leading to further neurological damage, coma, or death.

Given the patient's critical condition, it is essential to closely monitor and manage his treatment to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis, acute myocardial infarction, severe sepsis, acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and hepatic encephalopathy. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a history of ethanol use and has had persistent seizures. He is receiving antibiotics, vasopressors, and other medications to manage his condition. His vital signs are stable, but his laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate levels.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's severe sepsis is a significant risk factor for developing sepsis-related organ dysfunction, which can lead to acute kidney injury, respiratory failure, and cardiovascular instability.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure is a significant risk factor for developing respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory arrest.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is a significant risk factor for developing chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's acute myocardial infarction is a significant risk factor for developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's bacterial meningitis is a significant risk factor for developing neurological complications, such as meningitis-related encephalopathy, seizures, and brain abscesses.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia is a significant risk factor for developing cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
7. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's hepatic encephalopathy is a significant risk factor for developing hepatic failure, which can lead to coagulopathy, bleeding, and death.
8. Infection-related complications: The patient's bacterial meningitis is a significant risk factor for developing infection-related complications, such as sepsis, septic shock, and organ dysfunction.
9. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition is a significant risk factor for developing malnutrition-related complications, such as muscle wasting, weakness, and impaired wound healing.
10. Medication-related complications: The patient's medications, such as antibiotics, vasopressors, and sedatives, can cause adverse effects, such as allergic reactions, bleeding, and respiratory depression.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and possible myocardial infarction. The patient has been admitted to the ICU with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome, including respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and hepatic encephalopathy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a Vt of 450 mL, RR of 18, and FiO2 of 40%. The ABG results show a pH of 7.41, pCO2 of 38, and pO2 of 360.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hypotension, with a BP of 119/64 mmHg, and requires low-dose pressors. The patient has a low EF of 15% and a troponin level of 22.
* Renal: The patient has acute renal failure, with a Cr of 2.0 mg/dL, and is on CVVH with a net negative removal.
* Hepatic: The patient has hepatic encephalopathy, with a bilirubin level of 4.9 mg/dL and an albumin level of 5.4 g/dL.
* Neurological: The patient has seizures, possibly related to listeria meningitis, and is on propofol, dilantin, and phenobarb.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued seizures, potentially leading to further neurological damage
* Worsening of respiratory failure, potentially requiring more aggressive ventilatory support
* Progressive renal failure, potentially requiring further interventions such as dialysis
* Development of hepatic failure, potentially leading to coagulopathy and bleeding
* Continued hypotension, potentially leading to organ dysfunction and failure
* Development of sepsis, potentially leading to multi-organ failure

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuing antibiotic therapy for listeria meningitis
* Monitoring and managing seizures with propofol, dilantin, and phenobarb
* Weaning off propofol and phenobarb to assess seizure control
* Continuing CVVH to manage acute renal failure
* Monitoring and managing hypotension with low-dose pressors
* Continuing nutritional support with a renal diet
* Monitoring and managing glycemic control with a sliding scale insulin regimen

The patient's code status is full code, and the plan is to continue ICU care. A family meeting is planned today to discuss the patient's condition and treatment plan with the neurology team.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Seizure control: The patient's seizures are not well-controlled, and the use of three agents (propofol, dilantin, and phenobarbital) is concerning. There is a risk of further seizures or status epilepticus.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he requires vasopressors to maintain adequate perfusion. There is a risk of further hypotension or cardiac arrest.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is receiving CVVH to manage his fluid status. There is a risk of further renal damage or acute kidney injury.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated and requires oxygen therapy to maintain adequate oxygenation. There is a risk of further respiratory failure or ventilator-associated pneumonia.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver function is impaired, and he is at risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy. There is a risk of further liver damage or encephalopathy.
6. DIC: The patient's fibrinogen levels are low, and he is at risk of developing disseminated intravascular coagulation. There is a risk of further bleeding or thrombosis.
7. Infection: The patient has a history of listeria bacteremia and meningitis, and there is a risk of further infection or sepsis.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications. A family meeting is recommended to discuss the patient's condition and treatment plan with his family.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis, acute myocardial infarction, severe sepsis, acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and hepatic encephalopathy. He has a history of ethanol abuse and was diagnosed with listeria bacteremia at the onset of symptoms. The patient has been experiencing seizures, and treatment includes propofol, dilantin, and phenobarb. He is also receiving antibiotics for listeria meningitis and has a central venous catheter for CVVH (continuous venovenous hemofiltration). The patient's condition is critical, and he requires ongoing management of his multiple organ dysfunction.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued seizures: The patient's seizures are a concern, and the team needs to determine the underlying cause and develop a plan to manage them effectively.
2. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing further infections, particularly in the context of his immunocompromised state and the presence of a central venous catheter.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's acute myocardial infarction and low ejection fraction put him at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac tamponade.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure requires ongoing mechanical ventilation, and he is at risk for further respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or respiratory failure.
5. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure requires ongoing management, and he is at risk for further renal complications, such as acute tubular necrosis or chronic kidney disease.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia requires ongoing management, and he is at risk for further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
7. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's hepatic encephalopathy requires ongoing management, and he is at risk for further complications, such as bleeding or coagulopathy.
8. DIC: The patient's disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) requires ongoing management, and he is at risk for further complications, such as bleeding or organ failure.
9. Thiamine and folate deficiency: The patient's deficiency in thiamine and folate requires ongoing management, and he is at risk for further complications, such as Wernicke's encephalopathy or megaloblastic anemia.
10. Family meeting: The patient's family needs a meeting to discuss his condition, prognosis, and treatment options.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of EtOH cirrhosis, portal hypertension, and esophageal varices, who presented with listeria bacteremia and persistent seizures. He has been diagnosed with bacterial meningitis, myocardial infarction, acute respiratory failure, renal failure, and hyperkalemia. He is currently on propofol, dilantin, and phenobarb for seizure control, and antibiotics for listeria meningitis. He has a distended abdomen with ascites and is on CVVH for renal support. His cardiac function is compromised, and he is on low-dose pressors. He has a history of underlying infectious process, and his DIC is improving.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued seizure activity: The patient's seizure activity is ongoing, and the use of three agents (propofol, dilantin, and phenobarb) may be a concern. The patient's response to these medications needs to be closely monitored.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of underlying infectious process, and the use of antibiotics for listeria meningitis needs to be continued. The patient's white blood cell count and differential need to be closely monitored for signs of infection.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and the use of CVVH is necessary to support his renal function. The patient's creatinine levels need to be closely monitored for signs of worsening renal function.
4. Cardiac compromise: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and the use of low-dose pressors is necessary to support his blood pressure. The patient's troponin levels need to be closely monitored for signs of cardiac damage.
5. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels are elevated, and the use of potassium-lowering medications may be necessary. The patient's potassium levels need to be closely monitored for signs of hyperkalemia.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory function is compromised, and the use of mechanical ventilation is necessary to support his breathing. The patient's oxygen saturation levels need to be closely monitored for signs of respiratory distress.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of esophageal varices, and the use of anticoagulation therapy may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's bleeding risk needs to be closely monitored.
8. Sepsis: The patient has a history of underlying infectious process, and the use of antibiotics may increase the risk of sepsis. The patient's temperature and white blood cell count need to be closely monitored for signs of sepsis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue the use of propofol, dilantin, and phenobarb for seizure control, and monitor the patient's response to these medications.
2. Continue the use of antibiotics for listeria meningitis, and monitor the patient's white blood cell count and differential for signs of infection.
3. Continue the use of CVVH for renal support, and monitor the patient's creatinine levels for signs of worsening renal function.
4. Continue the use of low-dose pressors to support the patient's blood pressure, and monitor the patient's troponin levels for signs of cardiac damage.
5. Monitor the patient's potassium levels closely, and use potassium-lowering medications as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's oxygen saturation levels closely, and adjust the patient's respiratory support as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk closely, and use anticoagulation therapy with caution.
8. Monitor the patient's temperature and white blood cell count closely, and use antibiotics with caution to prevent sepsis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical condition. The patient has a history of seizure, bacteremia, and is currently experiencing status epilepticus. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2Â°C, heart rate of 69 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/57 mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 18, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, with elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and lactate dehydrogenase. The patient's renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 24 mg/dL. The patient's liver function is also impaired, with elevated levels of alanine transaminase and aspartate transaminase.

The patient's medical conditions include meningitis, myocardial infarction, acute respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. The patient is also experiencing hyperkalemia, hepatic encephalopathy, and ineffective coping.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Increased risk of sepsis-related organ dysfunction, including acute respiratory distress syndrome, acute kidney injury, and hepatic failure.
2. Prolonged mechanical ventilation and increased risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy.
4. Increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias and cardiogenic shock due to myocardial infarction.
5. Increased risk of renal failure and acute kidney injury due to bacteremia and sepsis.
6. Increased risk of hepatic failure and encephalopathy due to sepsis and liver dysfunction.
7. Increased risk of respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome due to sepsis and lung dysfunction.
8. Increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation due to sepsis and coagulopathy.

In order to prevent or manage these complications, the patient should receive aggressive supportive care, including fluid resuscitation, vasopressor therapy, and antibiotic treatment. The patient should also be closely monitored for signs of organ dysfunction and adjusted accordingly.

   The ET tube tip is 5 cm above the carina. The NG tube tip is in the

   Assessment and Plan: 76M with DM and cirrhosis presented to an OSH in
   septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis now w/ multiorgansystem
   failure and seizures.
   * Altered mental status:
   Persists w/o signs of improvement, probably multifactorial with CNS
   listerial infection, seizures, hepatic encephalopathy.  Not interactive
   off of sedatives.
   - Neurology input appreciated.
   - treat seizures as below
   - attempt to wean propofol
   - lactulose
   - MRI today
   .
   *. Seizures.  Pt has had multiple seizures may be due to CNS listeria
   infection. CT head noncontrast without mass or abscess.
   EEG showed persistent seizure activity.  NO seizures currently
   - Ativan prn
   - Neuro recs appreciated
   - Now on dilantin, checking regular and free dilantin levels and will
   f/u w/ neurology re dosing given artificially elevated albumin
   - started Phenobarbital, switch to PO this AM, follow levels next on
   [**5-16**]
   - discuss with neuro re: no LP for now
   *. Listeriosis with bacteremia and septic shock.  Likely c/b meningitis
   as presented w/ HA and lethargy.
   - Blood cx here pending w/ NGTD
   - Reculture if febrile, follow up pending micro at OSH re sensitivities
   - Continue ampicilin dose for CVVH. Added TMP-SMX for synergy.
   Anticipate 6 week course of amp, probably 3 week course of TMP-SMX
   - ID recommending LP - but very likely had meningitis would favor just
   treating him with 6wk CNS course. Will discuss with neuro re: ultility
   of LP -> not indicated currently
   - ID recs appreciated
   .
   * Hypotension
   Unclear etiology although clinically seems most consistent w/ sepsis
   (now w/ low-grade fevers on CVVH).  Mvo2 more consistent with
   cardiogenic than septic etiology (although unclear if CVVH could affect
   this).
   Multiple possible contributors including meds (eg ativan, dilantin),
   sepsis, volume removal with CVVH, poor pump function. Adrenal
   insufficiency also a possibility. On levophed currently.  Ran even on
   CVVH, Levophed lower today.  Likely multifactorial
   - Cortisol level not drastically low
   - Follow up cultures, CIS, infection tx as above
   - Continue levophed target MAP>60 -> attempt to wean to off
   - Follow lactate daily, recently stable
   - Cont to run CVVH even as levophed requirement appears lower
   .
   *. Acute oliguric renal failure: Most likely from ATN in the setting of
   hypotension.  Not fluid responsive.
   DDx includes ATN in setting of sepsis and recent vol depletion from
   diarrhea. Also consider HRS given cirrhosis. Abdominal compartment
   syndrome seems un likely. No IV contrast, from what I can tell from
   records. Could have AIN in the setting of abx but I think less likely.
   Renal U/S w/o hydro.
   - CVVH for now, but will cont to run even
   - Appreciate continued renal input
   *. Transaminitis with history of cirrhosis.
   LFTS have been trending down and cont to do so
   In setting of sepsis likely from shock liver. DDx includes med
   toxicity, hepatic congestion in setting of low EF. Acute infectious
   hepatitis less likely.
   - Continue to trends LFTs daily
   - Holding spironolactone
   - Liver following. DC
d albumin
   - elevated bilis may reflect lag in liver recovery. Also consider
   contrib from hemolysis (DIC) which is slowly improving
   *. Systolic heart failure w/ EF 15% from either recent or remote MI.
   - Continue ASA, BB
   - Monitor on telemetry given NSVT
   * DIC
   Fibrinogen continues to be low but will not give cryo given that he
   does not have any active bleeding.  Fibrino is increasing currently
   *. Tachyarrhythmia.  Pt had runsNSVT, maintained BP at the time. Likely
   predisposed with low EF, systemic infection, acid base disturbance in
   setting of renal failure
   - Continue monitoring on telemetry and continue metoprolol
   - Will keep pads on for now
   * Anemia:  Microcytic.  Drop from admission in setting of IVF. Stable
   on serial checks since yesterday. Pt did have borderline fibrinogen
   concerning for DIC
   - DIC labs daily
   - daily hct, transfuse hb>7, T+S
   * Thrombocytopenia: Likely from cirrhosis.  ? from DIC.  Stable
   - DIC labs daily
   *. DM
   - Hold home metformin
   - Insulin sliding scale, goal glucose <150
   *. Vent
   Atelectasis R base, will increase PEEP today. Gas shows improved pH.
   Trial of PSV again when returns from MRI

   *. Systolic heart failure w/ EF 15% from either recent or remote MI.
   - Continue ASA, BB
   - Monitor on telemetry given NSVT
   * DIC
   Fibrinogen continues to be low but will not give cryo given that he
   does not have any active bleeding.  Fibrino is increasing currently
   *. Tachyarrhythmia.  Pt had runsNSVT, maintained BP at the time. Likely
   predisposed with low EF, systemic infection, acid base disturbance in
   setting of renal failure
   - Continue monitoring on telemetry and continue metoprolol
   - Will keep pads on for now
   * Anemia:  Microcytic.  Drop from admission in setting of IVF. Stable
   on serial checks since yesterday. Pt did have borderline fibrinogen
   concerning for DIC
   - DIC labs daily
   - daily hct, transfuse hb>7, T+S
   * Thrombocytopenia: Likely from cirrhosis.  ? from DIC.  Stable
   - DIC labs daily
   *. DM
   - Hold home metformin
   - Insulin sliding scale, goal glucose <150
   *. Vent
   Atelectasis R base, will increase PEEP today. Gas shows improved pH.
   Trial of PSV again when returns from MRI

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Seizure control: The patient has had multiple seizures, and the current treatment plan includes phenobarbital and dilantin. However, the patient's EEG showed persistent seizure activity, and the neurology team may need to reassess the treatment plan.
2. Listeriosis: The patient has a confirmed case of listeriosis with bacteremia and septic shock. The ID team recommends continuing ampicillin for 6 weeks and adding TMP-SMX for synergy. However, the patient's meningitis may require a longer course of treatment.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be multifactorial, including sepsis, medications, volume removal with CVVH, and poor pump function. The team should continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Acute oliguric renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely due to ATN in the setting of hypotension. The team should continue to run CVVH and monitor the patient's kidney function.
5. Transaminitis: The patient's liver function tests have been trending down, and the team should continue to monitor them daily.
6. Systolic heart failure: The patient has a low EF and may have had a recent or remote MI. The team should continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. DIC: The patient has a low fibrinogen level, which may be contributing to their bleeding diathesis. The team should continue to monitor the patient's DIC labs and adjust treatment accordingly.
8. Tachyarrhythmia: The patient has had runs of NSVT, which may be related to their low EF, systemic infection, and acid-base disturbance. The team should continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust treatment accordingly.
9. Anemia: The patient has a microcytic anemia, which may be related to their IVF and potential bleeding diathesis. The team should continue to monitor the patient's hemoglobin levels and transfuse as necessary.
10. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be related to their cirrhosis and potential bleeding diathesis. The team should continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust treatment accordingly.
11. DM: The patient has a history of DM and should be monitored for hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
12. Ventilator management: The patient has a ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and should be monitored for signs of infection. The team should also continue to adjust the patient's ventilator settings to optimize their lung function.

Overall, the patient is at risk for multiple complications, and the team should continue to monitor their condition closely and adjust treatment accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-inch tall individual who is intubated and sedated due to encephalopathy. The patient has a history of seizures, bacteremia, and is currently experiencing sepsis with organ dysfunction. The patient has a high risk of developing medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated, and there is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation.
2. Renal failure: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) and is at risk of developing chronic kidney disease (CKD) if not managed properly.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient has elevated liver enzymes and is at risk of developing further liver damage if not managed properly.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient has elevated potassium levels, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications if not managed properly.
5. Sepsis: The patient has severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, which can lead to multiple organ failure if not managed properly.
6. Myocardial infarction: The patient has a high risk of developing myocardial infarction (MI) due to the presence of bacteremia and sepsis.
7. Meningitis: The patient has bacterial meningitis, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
9. DVT: The patient has a high risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to the prolonged use of central venous catheters.
10. Stress ulcer: The patient has a high risk of developing stress ulcer due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation and sedation.

To manage these complications, the patient requires close monitoring, and the ICU team should focus on:

1. Maintaining adequate ventilation and oxygenation.
2. Managing blood pressure and cardiac output.
3. Controlling hyperkalemia and hypokalemia.
4. Monitoring liver function and managing liver failure.
5. Managing sepsis and preventing further organ dysfunction.
6. Preventing DVT and stress ulcer.
7. Monitoring for signs of myocardial infarction and managing accordingly.
8. Monitoring for signs of meningitis and managing accordingly.
9. Monitoring for signs of respiratory failure and managing accordingly.

In conclusion, the patient is at high risk of developing multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and ensure optimal care.

   septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis now w/ multiorgansystem
   failure and seizures.
   * Altered mental status:
   Persists w/o signs of improvement, probably multifactorial with CNS
   listerial infection, seizures, hepatic encephalopathy.  Not interactive
   off of sedatives.
   - Neurology input appreciated.
   - treat seizures as below
   - attempt to wean propofol
   .
   *. Seizures.  Pt has had multiple seizures may be due to CNS listeria
   infection. CT head noncontrast without mass or abscess.
   EEG showed persistent seizure activity.  MRI performed.  NO seizures
   currently
   - Ativan prn
   - Neuro recs appreciated
   - Now on dilantin, checking regular and free dilantin levels and will
   f/u w/ neurology re dosing given artificially elevated albumin
   - started Phenobarbital, switch to PO this AM, follow levels
   - discuss with neuro re: no LP for now
   - MRI performed, will follow up results
   *. Listeriosis with bacteremia and septic shock.  Likely c/b meningitis
   as presented w/ HA and lethargy.
   - Blood cx here pending w/ NGTD
   - Reculture if febrile, follow up pending micro at OSH re sensitivities
   - Continue ampicilin dose for CVVH. Added TMP-SMX for synergy.
   Anticipate 6 week course of amp, probably 3 week course of TMP-SMX
   - ID recommending LP - but very likely had meningitis would favor just
   treating him with 6wk CNS course. Will discuss with neuro re: ultility
   of LP -> not indicated currently
   - ID recs appreciated
   .
   * Hypotension
   Unclear etiology although clinically seems most consistent w/ sepsis
   (now w/ low-grade fevers on CVVH).  Mvo2 more consistent with
   cardiogenic than septic etiology (although unclear if CVVH could affect
   this).
   Multiple possible contributors including meds (eg ativan, dilantin),
   sepsis, volume removal with CVVH, poor pump function. Adrenal
   insufficiency also a possibility. On levophed currently.  Ran even on
   CVVH, Levophed lower today.  Likely multifactorial
   - Cortisol level not drastically low
   - Follow up cultures, CIS, infection tx as above
   - Continue levophed target MAP>60 -> attempt to wean to off
   - Follow lactate daily, recently stable
   - Cont to run CVVH even as levophed requirement appears lower
   .
   * r/o Ventilator acquired pneumonia
   Sputum without pathogen identified yet. Temp curve improving on
   antibiotics.  WBC stable
   - Continue zosyn x8d course (d1 = [**5-10**])
   - Will D/C vanco
   - Follow up pending cultures and CIS
   .
   *. Acute oliguric renal failure: Most likely from ATN in the setting of
   hypotension.  Not fluid responsive.
   DDx includes ATN in setting of sepsis and recent vol depletion from
   diarrhea. Also consider HRS given cirrhosis. Abdominal compartment
   syndrome seems un likely. No IV contrast, from what I can tell from
   records. Could have AIN in the setting of abx but I think less likely.
   Renal U/S w/o hydro.
   - CVVH for now, but will cont to run even
   - Appreciate continued renal input
   *. Transaminitis with history of cirrhosis.
   LFTS have been trending down and cont to do so
   In setting of sepsis likely from shock liver. DDx includes med
   toxicity, hepatic congestion in setting of low EF. Acute infectious
   hepatitis less likely.
   - Continue albumin 50mg [**Hospital1 **] per hepatology recommendations
   - Continue to trends LFTs daily
   - Holding spironolactone
   - Liver following
   - elevated bilis may reflect lag in liver recovery. Also consider
   contrib from hemolysis (DIC) which is slowly improving
   *. Systolic heart failure w/ EF 15% from either recent or remote MI.
   - Continue ASA, BB
   - Monitor on telemetry given NSVT
   * DIC
   Fibrinogen continues to be low but will not give cryo given that he
   does not have any active bleeding.  Fibrino is increasing currently
   - monitor fibrinogen periodically
   *. Tachyarrhythmia.  Pt had runsNSVT, maintained BP at the time. Likely
   predisposed with low EF, systemic infection, acid base disturbance in
   setting of renal failure
   - Continue monitoring on telemetry and continue metoprolol
   - Will keep pads on for now
   * Anemia:  Microcytic.  Drop from admission in setting of IVF. Stable
   on serial checks since yesterday. Pt did have borderline fibrinogen
   concerning for DIC
   - DIC labs daily
   - daily hct, transfuse hb>7, T+S
   * Thrombocytopenia: Likely from cirrhosis.  ? from DIC.  Stable
   - DIC labs daily
   *. DM
   - Hold home metformin
   - Insulin sliding scale, goal glucose <150
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2134-5-7**] 01:41 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2134-5-7**] 02:19 PM

   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds , Family
   meeting held , ICU consent signed Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus (DM), cirrhosis, and a recent hospitalization for septic shock likely secondary to listeriosis. The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. The patient has a bilateral pleural effusion and a minimal amount of bilateral pleural effusion.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15%, and is on aspirin and beta-blockers. The patient has a tachyarrhythmia with runs of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) and is being monitored on telemetry.
* Renal: The patient has acute oliguric renal failure, likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) in the setting of hypotension. The patient is on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).
* Hepatic: The patient has transaminitis, likely due to shock liver, and is being treated with albumin.
* Hematological: The patient has a microcytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, likely due to cirrhosis and possibly due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
* Endocrine: The patient has DM and is being treated with insulin sliding scale.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, likely due to sepsis, listerial infection, and hepatic encephalopathy. The patient is being treated with anticonvulsants and is being monitored for seizures.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate further, leading to respiratory failure.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's tachyarrhythmia and low ejection fraction make them at risk for cardiac arrest.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute oliguric renal failure can worsen, leading to chronic renal failure.
* Hepatic failure: The patient's transaminitis and cirrhosis make them at risk for hepatic failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and septic shock can lead to further organ dysfunction and death.
* DIC: The patient's thrombocytopenia and low fibrinogen levels make them at risk for DIC, which can lead to bleeding and organ failure.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status and hepatic encephalopathy can worsen, leading to further neurological deterioration.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following interventions are recommended:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust medications as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dialysis settings as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's hepatic function and adjust medications as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's hematological status and adjust transfusions as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's endocrine status and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust anticonvulsant therapy as needed.
* Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's treatment regimen to prevent further sepsis.
* Consider adding anticoagulation therapy to the patient's treatment regimen to prevent further DIC.

   Assessment and Plan: 76M with DM and cirrhosis presented to an OSH in
   septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis now w/ multiorgansystem
   failure and seizures.
   * Altered mental status:
   Persists w/o signs of improvement, probably multifactorial with CNS
   listerial infection, seizures, hepatic encephalopathy.  Not interactive
   off of sedatives.
   - Neurology input appreciated.
   - treat seizures as below
   - attempt to wean propofol
   .
   *. Seizures.  Pt has had multiple seizures may be due to CNS listeria
   infection. CT head noncontrast without mass or abscess.
   EEG showed persistent seizure activity.
   - Ativan prn
   - Neuro recs appreciated
   - Now on dilantin, checking regular and free dilantin levels and will
   f/u w/ neurology re dosing given artificially elevated albumin
   - started phenobarbital
   - discuss with neuro re: utility of repeat imaging vs. LP
   *. Listeriosis with bacteremia and septic shock.  Likely c/b meningitis
   as presented w/ HA and lethargy.
   - Blood cx here pending w/ NGTD
   - Reculture if febrile, follow up pending micro at OSH re sensitivities
   - Continue ampicilin dose for CVVH. Added TMP-SMX for synergy.
   Anticipate 6 week course of amp, probably 3 week course of TMP-SMX
   - ID recommending LP - but very likely had meningitis would favor just
   treating him with 6wk CNS course. Will discuss with neuro re: ultility
   of LP
   - ID recs appreciated
   .
   * Hypotension
   Unclear etiology although clinically seems most consistent w/ sepsis
   (now w/ low-grade fevers on CVVH).  Mvo2 more consistent with
   cardiogenic than septic etiology (although unclear if CVVH could affect
   this).
   Multiple possible contributors including meds (eg ativan, dilantin),
   sepsis, volume removal with CVVH, poor pump function. Adrenal
   insufficiency also a possibility. On levophed currently
   - Cortisol level not drastically low
   - Follow up cultures, CIS, infection tx as above
   - Continue levophed target MAP>60 -> attempt to wean
   - Follow lactate daily, recently stable
   - Will change CVVH to run even to see if this improves hypotension
   .
   * r/o Ventilator acquired pneumonia
   Sputum without pathogen identified yet. Temp curve improving on
   antibiotics
   - Continue zosyn x8d course (d1 = [**5-10**])
   - Will D/C vanco
   - Follow up pending cultures and CIS
   .
   *. Acute oliguric renal failure: Most likely from ATN in the setting of
   hypotension.  Not fluid responsive.
   DDx includes ATN in setting of sepsis and recent vol depletion from
   diarrhea. Also consider HRS given cirrhosis. Abdominal compartment
   syndrome seems un likely. No IV contrast, from what I can tell from
   records. Could have AIN in the setting of abx but I think less likely.
   Renal U/S w/o hydro.
   - CVVH for now, but will run even now to see if this improves
   hypotensiion
   - Appreciate continued renal input
   *. Transaminitis with history of cirrhosis.
   LFTS have been trending down
   In setting of sepsis likely from shock liver. DDx includes med
   toxicity, hepatic congestion in setting of low EF. Acute infectious
   hepatitis less likely.
   - Continue albumin 50mg [**Hospital1 **] per hepatology recommendations
   - Continue to trends LFTs daily
   - Holding spironolactone
   - Liver following
   - elevated bilis may reflect lag in liver recovery. Also consider
   contrib from hemolysis (DIC). Check D bili today.
   *. Systolic heart failure w/ EF 15% from either recent or remote MI.
   - Continue ASA, BB
   - Monitor on telemetry given NSVT
   * DIC
   Fibrinogen continues to be low but will not give cryo given that he
   does not have any active bleeding
   - monitor fibrinogen.
   *. Tachyarrhythmia.  Pt had runsNSVT, maintained BP at the time. Likely
   predisposed with low EF, systemic infection, acid base disturbance in
   setting of renal failure
   - Continue monitoring on telemetry and continue metoprolol
   - Will keep pads on for now
   * Anemia:  Microcytic.  Drop from admission in setting of IVF. Stable
   on serial checks since yesterday. Pt did have borderline fibrinogen
   concerning for DIC
   - DIC labs daily
   - daily hct, transfuse hb>7, T+S
   * Thrombocytopenia: Likely from cirrhosis.  ? from DIC.
   - DIC labs daily
   *. DM
   - Hold home metformin
   - Insulin sliding scale, goal glucose <150
   ICU Care

   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Seizure control: The patient has had multiple seizures, and it is crucial to continue monitoring and managing them effectively to prevent further seizures and potential brain damage.
2. Sepsis: The patient has bacteremia and septic shock, which can lead to multiorgan failure, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, which may require mechanical ventilation and close monitoring to prevent further deterioration.
4. Renal failure: The patient has acute oliguric renal failure, which may require ongoing CVVH and close monitoring to prevent further kidney damage.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient has hepatic encephalopathy, which can lead to worsening mental status and potential brain damage if not managed effectively.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient has systolic heart failure with an EF of 15%, which may require ongoing monitoring and management to prevent further cardiac deterioration.
7. DIC: The patient has low fibrinogen levels, which may indicate DIC, a potentially life-threatening condition.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which may be related to cirrhosis or DIC.
9. Anemia: The patient has microcytic anemia, which may be related to chronic blood loss, IVF, or underlying medical conditions.
10. Infection control: The patient has a high risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and other infections due to his prolonged ICU stay and multiple lines.
11. Metabolic complications: The patient has diabetes, which requires ongoing management to prevent hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
12. Nutritional support: The patient requires ongoing nutritional support to prevent malnutrition and optimize his overall health.

In terms of assessment and plan, the patient's condition is complex and multifaceted. The patient has a high risk of developing further complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent these complications and optimize his outcome. The patient's treatment plan includes ongoing management of his seizures, sepsis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and other medical conditions, as well as ongoing monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of diabetes, cirrhosis, and septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) and is being treated for multi-organ failure, including respiratory, cardiac, and renal failure.

The patient's condition is critical, and he is at risk for developing further complications. The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Seizures: The patient has had multiple seizures and is at risk for further seizures due to his underlying condition.
2. Infection: The patient has a bacteremia and is at risk for developing further infections, including pneumonia and meningitis.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a low ejection fraction and is at risk for cardiac arrest.
4. Renal failure: The patient has acute oliguric renal failure and is at risk for further deterioration in his renal function.
5. Hepatic failure: The patient has transaminitis and is at risk for further deterioration in his liver function.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient has a low fibrinogen level and is at risk for bleeding.
7. Anemia: The patient has microcytic anemia and is at risk for further anemia.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia and is at risk for bleeding.
9. Respiratory failure: The patient has respiratory failure and is at risk for further deterioration in his respiratory status.
10. Sepsis: The patient has septic shock and is at risk for further deterioration in his condition.

The patient's treatment plan includes antibiotics, vasopressors, and supportive care. The patient is also being monitored closely for signs of further deterioration in his condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical complications. The patient had a seizure and is currently in the ICU. 

The patient's condition is complicated by meningitis/cerebritis, small areas of septic infarcts, and myocardial infarction (AMI). The patient has also developed acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and hyperkalemia. Additionally, the patient has sepsis with organ dysfunction, and the patient's liver function is compromised, leading to hepatic encephalopathy. 

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate levels, indicating ongoing sepsis and organ dysfunction. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with elevated potassium and phosphorus levels. 

The patient's medication list includes antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and medications for glycemic control, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis. The patient is also receiving nutritional support through a nasogastric tube. 

The patient's current medical status is critical, and the patient is at high risk for further complications. The patient's code status is full code, and the patient is currently in the ICU. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Further deterioration of respiratory and renal function
2. Development of cardiac arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances
3. Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy
4. Progression of sepsis and organ dysfunction
5. Development of further neurological complications, such as increased intracranial pressure
6. Increased risk of nosocomial infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia
7. Further compromise of liver function, leading to worsening encephalopathy
8. Development of acute pancreatitis due to hyperglycemia and electrolyte imbalances

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent further complications and improve the patient's outcome.

   Assessment and Plan: 76M with DM and cirrhosis presented to an OSH in
   septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis now w/ multiorgansystem
   failure and presumed meningitis/cerebritis and difficult to control
   seizures.
   * Altered mental status:
   Persists w/o signs of improvement, probably multifactorial with CNS
   listerial infection, seizures, hepatic encephalopathy.  Not interactive
   off of sedatives.  MRI showing persistent signs of
   meningitis/cerebritis, and areas of possible septic infarct
   - Neurology input appreciated.
   - treat seizures as below
   - maintain off propofol
   - lactulose
   - f/u MRI final read -> discuss with neurology re: findings
   .
   *. Seizures.  Pt has had multiple seizures may be due to CNS listeria
   infection. CT head noncontrast without mass or abscess.
   EEG showed persistent seizure activity.  Now without seizures currently
   on 2 agents.  Given MRI findings, unclear if septic infarcts serving as
   nidus for seizure activity
   - Ativan prn
   - Neuro recs appreciated
   - Now on dilantin, checking regular and free dilantin levels and will
   f/u w/ neurology re dosing given artificially elevated albumin
   - Cont Phenobarbital.  Level at 21.7 and goal 20, would continue at
   current dose, follow levels next on [**5-16**]
   - discuss with neuro re: no LP for now
   *. Listeriosis with bacteremia and septic shock.  Likely c/b meningitis
   as presented w/ HA and lethargy.
   - Blood cx here pending w/ NGTD
   - Reculture if febrile, follow up pending micro at OSH re sensitivities
   - Continue ampicilin dose for CVVH. Added TMP-SMX for synergy.
   Anticipate 6 week course of amp, probably 3 week course of TMP-SMX
   - ID recommending LP - but very likely had meningitis would favor just
   treating him with 6wk CNS course. Will discuss with neuro re: ultility
   of LP -> not indicated currently
   - ID recs appreciated
   .
   * Hypotension
   Unclear etiology although clinically seems most consistent w/ sepsis
   (low-grade fevers on CVVH).  Mvo2 more consistent with cardiogenic than
   septic etiology (although unclear if CVVH could affect this).
   Multiple possible contributors including meds (eg ativan, dilantin),
   sepsis, volume removal with CVVH, poor pump function. Adrenal
   insufficiency less likely. On levophed currently.  Ran even on CVVH,
   Levophed lower today.  Likely multifactorial
   - Cortisol level not drastically low
   - Follow up cultures, CIS, infection tx as above
   - Continue levophed target MAP>60 -> attempt to wean to off
   - Follow lactate daily, recently stable
   - Cont to run CVVH even as levophed requirement appears lower overall
   .
   *. Acute oliguric renal failure: Most likely from ATN in the setting of
   hypotension.  Not fluid responsive.
   DDx includes ATN in setting of sepsis and recent vol depletion from
   diarrhea. Also consider HRS given cirrhosis. Abdominal compartment
   syndrome seems un likely. No IV contrast, from what I can tell from
   records. Could have AIN in the setting of abx but I think less likely.
   Renal U/S w/o hydro.
   - CVVH for now, but will cont to run even
   - Appreciate continued renal input
   - Replaced femoral HD line for IJ HD line on [**5-14**]
   *. Transaminitis with history of cirrhosis.
   LFTS have been trending down/stable and cont to do so
   In setting of sepsis likely from shock liver. DDx includes med
   toxicity, hepatic congestion in setting of low EF. Acute infectious
   hepatitis less likely.
   - Continue to trends LFTs periodically
   - Holding spironolactone
   - Liver following. DC
d albumin
   - elevated bilis may reflect lag in liver recovery. Also consider
   contrib from hemolysis (DIC) which is slowly improving
   *. Systolic heart failure w/ EF 15% from either recent or remote MI.
   - Continue ASA, BB
   - Monitor on telemetry given NSVT
   * DIC
   Fibrinogen continues to be low but will not give cryo given that he
   does not have any active bleeding.  Fibrino is increasing currently
   *. Tachyarrhythmia.  Pt had runsNSVT, maintained BP at the time. Likely
   predisposed with low EF, systemic infection, acid base disturbance in
   setting of renal failure
   - Continue monitoring on telemetry and continue metoprolol
   - Will keep pads on for now
   * Anemia:  Microcytic.  Drop from admission in setting of IVF. Stable
   on serial checks since yesterday. Pt did have borderline fibrinogen
   concerning for DIC
   - DIC labs every other day
   - daily hct, transfuse hb>7, T+S
   * Thrombocytopenia: Likely from cirrhosis.  ? from DIC.  Stable
   - DIC labs every other day
   *. DM
   - Hold home metformin
   - Insulin sliding scale, goal glucose <150
   *. Vent
   Atelectasis R base.  Put on PSV with increased PEEP [**5-14**], patient
   tolerating well.  ABG has been stable
   - Cont PSV ventilation with high PEEP for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren Renal (Full) - [**2134-5-15**] 02:00 AM 20 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2134-5-7**] 01:41 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2134-5-7**] 02:19 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2134-5-14**] 04:26 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication: Family meeting held , ICU consent signed Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a chief complaint of seizure. He has been admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of septic shock, meningitis, cerebritis, and multi-organ system failure.

The patient's neurological status is critical, with persistent altered mental status, likely due to CNS listerial infection, seizures, and hepatic encephalopathy. He has had multiple seizures, which may be due to CNS listeria infection. The patient is currently on two anticonvulsant medications and is being monitored closely.

The patient's cardiac status is also critical, with a low ejection fraction (EF) of 15% due to recent or remote myocardial infarction. He is being treated with ASA and BB, and is being monitored on telemetry for tachyarrhythmias.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with acute respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. He has been placed on PSV ventilation with high PEEP, which he is tolerating well.

The patient's renal status is critical, with acute oliguric renal failure due to ATN in the setting of hypotension. He is being treated with CVVH, and his creatinine levels are increasing.

The patient's liver status is also critical, with transaminitis and elevated bilirubin levels. He has a history of cirrhosis, and his LFTs have been trending down/stable.

The patient's coagulation status is critical, with low fibrinogen levels and a risk of bleeding. He is being monitored closely for DIC, and is receiving anticoagulant therapy.

The patient's blood sugar control is critical, with a diagnosis of DM. He is being treated with insulin sliding scale, and his goal glucose level is <150.

The patient's nutritional status is critical, with a diagnosis of malnutrition. He is being fed via a nasogastric tube, and is receiving a renal formula.

The patient's prophylactic measures include DVT prophylaxis with boots and SQ UF heparin, stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI, and VAP prophylaxis with HOB elevation, mouth care, and daily wake-up.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued seizures and neurological decline
* Cardiac arrest due to tachyarrhythmias or low EF
* Respiratory failure requiring increased mechanical ventilation
* Renal failure requiring dialysis
* Liver failure requiring liver transplantation
* Coagulation disorders requiring transfusions
* Blood sugar control issues requiring insulin adjustments
* Nutritional deficiencies requiring adjustments to his nutritional regimen
* Infection control issues requiring close monitoring for sepsis

It is essential to continue close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan: 76M with DM and cirrhosis presented to an OSH in
   septic shock, likely secondary to listeriosis now w/ multiorgansystem
   failure and presumed meningitis/cerebritis and difficult to control
   seizures.
   * Altered mental status:
   Persists w/o signs of improvement, probably multifactorial with CNS
   listerial infection, seizures, hepatic encephalopathy.  Not interactive
   off of sedatives.  MRI showing persistent signs of
   meningitis/cerebritis, and areas of possible septic infarct
   - Neurology input appreciated.
   - treat seizures as below
   - maintain off propofol
   - lactulose
   - f/u MRI final read -> discuss with neurology re: findings
   .
   *. Seizures.  Pt has had multiple seizures may be due to CNS listeria
   infection. CT head noncontrast without mass or abscess.
   EEG showed persistent seizure activity.  Now without seizures currently
   on 2 agents.  Given MRI findings, unclear if septic infarcts serving as
   nidus for seizure activity
   - Ativan prn
   - Neuro recs appreciated
   - Now on dilantin, checking regular and free dilantin levels and will
   f/u w/ neurology re dosing given artificially elevated albumin
   - Cont Phenobarbital.  Level at 21.7 and goal 20, would continue at
   current dose, follow levels next on [**5-16**]
   - discuss with neuro re: no LP for now
   *. Listeriosis with bacteremia and septic shock.  Likely c/b meningitis
   as presented w/ HA and lethargy.
   - Blood cx here pending w/ NGTD
   - Reculture if febrile, follow up pending micro at OSH re sensitivities
   - Continue ampicilin dose for CVVH. Added TMP-SMX for synergy.
   Anticipate 6 week course of amp, probably 3 week course of TMP-SMX
   - ID recommending LP - but very likely had meningitis would favor just
   treating him with 6wk CNS course. Will discuss with neuro re: ultility
   of LP -> not indicated currently
   - ID recs appreciated
   .
   * Hypotension
   Unclear etiology although clinically seems most consistent w/ sepsis
   (low-grade fevers on CVVH).  Mvo2 more consistent with cardiogenic than
   septic etiology (although unclear if CVVH could affect this).
   Multiple possible contributors including meds (eg ativan, dilantin),
   sepsis, volume removal with CVVH, poor pump function. Adrenal
   insufficiency less likely. On levophed currently.  Ran even on CVVH,
   Levophed lower today.  Likely multifactorial
   - Cortisol level not drastically low
   - Follow up cultures, CIS, infection tx as above
   - Continue levophed target MAP>60 -> attempt to wean to off
   - Follow lactate daily, recently stable
   - Cont to run CVVH even as levophed requirement appears lower overall
   .
   *. Acute oliguric renal failure: Most likely from ATN in the setting of
   hypotension.  Not fluid responsive.
   DDx includes ATN in setting of sepsis and recent vol depletion from
   diarrhea. Also consider HRS given cirrhosis. Abdominal compartment
   syndrome seems un likely. No IV contrast, from what I can tell from
   records. Could have AIN in the setting of abx but I think less likely.
   Renal U/S w/o hydro.
   - CVVH for now, but will cont to run even
   - Appreciate continued renal input
   - Replaced femoral HD line for IJ HD line on [**5-14**]
   *. Transaminitis with history of cirrhosis.
   LFTS have been trending down/stable and cont to do so
   In setting of sepsis likely from shock liver. DDx includes med
   toxicity, hepatic congestion in setting of low EF. Acute infectious
   hepatitis less likely.
   - Continue to trends LFTs periodically
   - Holding spironolactone
   - Liver following. DC
d albumin
   - elevated bilis may reflect lag in liver recovery. Also consider
   contrib from hemolysis (DIC) which is slowly improving
   *. Systolic heart failure w/ EF 15% from either recent or remote MI.
   - Continue ASA, BB
   - Monitor on telemetry given NSVT
   * DIC
   Fibrinogen continues to be low but will not give cryo given that he
   does not have any active bleeding.  Fibrino is increasing currently
   *. Tachyarrhythmia.  Pt had runsNSVT, maintained BP at the time. Likely
   predisposed with low EF, systemic infection, acid base disturbance in
   setting of renal failure
   - Continue monitoring on telemetry and continue metoprolol
   - Will keep pads on for now
   * Anemia:  Microcytic.  Drop from admission in setting of IVF. Stable
   on serial checks since yesterday. Pt did have borderline fibrinogen
   concerning for DIC
   - DIC labs every other day
   - daily hct, transfuse hb>7, T+S
   * Thrombocytopenia: Likely from cirrhosis.  ? from DIC.  Stable
   - DIC labs every other day
   *. DM
   - Hold home metformin
   - Insulin sliding scale, goal glucose <150
   *. Vent
   Atelectasis R base.  Put on PSV with increased PEEP [**5-14**], patient
   tolerating well.  ABG has been stable
   - Cont PSV ventilation with high PEEP for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren Renal (Full) - [**2134-5-15**] 02:00 AM 20 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2134-5-7**] 01:41 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2134-5-7**] 02:19 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2134-5-14**] 04:26 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication: Family meeting held , ICU consent signed Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU
